elements.content: Small changes to the reaction conditions differentiate between two metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), {[Ce2(H2O)(bpdc)3(dmf)2]·2(dmf)} n (1) and {[Ce4(H2O)5(bpdc)6(dmf)]·x(dmf)} n (2), that were solvothermally synthesized from cerium(III) nitrate hexahydrate and 2,2′-bipyridine-5,5′-dicarboxylic acid (H2bpdc) in dimethylformamide (dmf). The two compounds illustrate how the flexibility of the coordination geometry of CeIII translates into MOFs, the formation of which readily adapts to different solvent environments.
elements.clean_text: Small changes to the reaction conditions differentiate between two metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), {[Ce2(H2O)(bpdc)3(dmf)2]⋅2(dmf)} n  (1) and {[Ce4(H2O)5(bpdc)6(dmf)]⋅x(dmf)} n  (2), that were solvothermally synthesized from cerium(III) nitrate hexahydrate and 2,2'-bipyridine-5,5'-dicarboxylic acid (H2bpdc) in dimethylformamide (dmf). The two compounds illustrate how the flexibility of the coordination geometry of CeIII translates into MOFs, the formation of which readily adapts to different solvent environments.

elements.content: Two cerium(III) 2,2′-bipyridine-5,5′-dicarboxylate-based 3D coordination networks highlight the ability of CeIII ions to adopt different coordination environments upon subtle changes to the reaction conditions, producing metal−organic frameworks that integrate varying crystal solvent contents.
elements.clean_text: Two cerium(III) 2,2'-bipyridine-5,5'-dicarboxylate-based 3D coordination networks highlight the ability of CeIII ions to adopt different coordination environments upon subtle changes to the reaction conditions, producing metal-organic frameworks that integrate varying crystal solvent contents.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have attracted tremendous interest during the last decades not only due to their intriguing architectures and topologies but also because of their promising applications (for recent reviews and monographs, see ref ). A huge diversity of organic ligands acting as linkers between metal ions or metal clusters has been utilized for the preparation and functionalization of MOFs. Nevertheless, it remains a challenge to identify methods to fine tune the structural features of MOFs, for example, their topology nets or accessible pore or channel dimensions, with respect to desired properties. Moreover, the formation of such coordination frameworks with open donor sites for insertion of additional metal centers opens new opportunities for a broad range of properties and their subsequent applications. In this context, the multidentate ligand 2,2′-bipyridine-5,5′-dicarboxylate (bpdc2–) is an excellent candidate. Additional to a bipyridyl moiety that can chelate to metal atom via N donors, the two carboxylic groups are characterized by an extraordinary coordination ability, with each of them able to coordinate to four metal centers displaying 19 different coordination modes. The bpdc ligand can coordinate up to ten metal ions displaying different coordination modes as shown in Scheme and forming a variety of multidimensional structures (Table S1, ). A large number of different factors such as metal identity, the number and nature of ancillary ligands involved, the existence of charge-balancing outer-sphere cations and anions, the groups able to form hydrogen bonds, different reaction conditions, and others have influence on the coordination features displayed by this ligand in its complexes. In contrast to molecular (0D) complexes in which bpdc almost always acts as a chelating ligand exclusively via the bipyridine moiety (type g in Scheme ), in one-dimensional chain coordination polymers based on nickel(II) ions and additional N-donor cyclam ligands, [Ni(cyclam)(bpdc)] n , the bpdc ligand only involves carboxylate groups in the bonding and adopts type a in Scheme , while in the 1D copper(II) coordination polymer [Cu(H2bpdc)Cl] n the coordination occurs also via a bipyridyl moiety. Remarkably, the bpdc ligand often employs both carboxylate groups and the bipyridine unit to form a wide range of two-dimensional networks, which include different homo- or heterometallic centers. For example, in a series of 2D coordination polymers based on homometallic Fe(II), Ni(II), Co(II), and Zn(II) ions and bpdc that have been hydrothermally synthesized, the bpdc ligand used all donor sites to build up an extended network. Similar behavior is observed in the heterometallic 2D polymers that include Pt(II)/Y(III), Pt(II)/Gd(III), Pt(II)/Rb(I), and Ru(IV)/Zn(II) ions, except a Cu(II)/V(IV)-based coordination polymer with coordination only to the bipyridine moiety. In the case of three-dimensional coordination polymers of Nd(III), K(I), Zn(II), and Sm(III), the bpdc used carboxylate groups to bind the metal centers and its N donor sites were left open, while in homo- or heterometallic MOFs of Pb(II), Zn(II), Mn(II), Ru(II)/Zn(II), Mn(I)/Mn(II), and Re(I)/Mn (II), all donor sites of bpdc bind. Note that the Ru(II) and Pt(II) complexes with bpdc, [Ru(Hbpdc)2(X)2], and [Pt(bpdc)(tdt)] (tdt = 3,4-toluenedithiolate) and its tetrabutylammoium salt, attached to a TiO2 substrate, have been used as sensitizers in solar cells. The aforementioned linear Ni(II) coordination polymers with open bpdc N-donor sites exhibit permanent porosity, hydrogen storage capacity, and selective organic guest binding ability.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have attracted tremendous interest during the last decades not only due to their intriguing architectures and topologies but also because of their promising applications (for recent reviews and monographs, see ref ). A huge diversity of organic ligands acting as linkers between metal ions or metal clusters has been utilized for the preparation and functionalization of MOFs. Nevertheless, it remains a challenge to identify methods to fine tune the structural features of MOFs, for example, their topology nets or accessible pore or channel dimensions, with respect to desired properties. Moreover, the formation of such coordination frameworks with open donor sites for insertion of additional metal centers opens new opportunities for a broad range of properties and their subsequent applications. In this context, the multidentate ligand 2,2'-bipyridine-5,5'-dicarboxylate (bpdc2-) is an excellent candidate. Additional to a bipyridyl moiety that can chelate to metal atom via N donors, the two carboxylic groups are characterized by an extraordinary coordination ability, with each of them able to coordinate to four metal centers displaying 19 different coordination modes. The bpdc ligand can coordinate up to ten metal ions displaying different coordination modes as shown in Scheme  and forming a variety of multidimensional structures (Table S1, ). A large number of different factors such as metal identity, the number and nature of ancillary ligands involved, the existence of charge-balancing outer-sphere cations and anions, the groups able to form hydrogen bonds, different reaction conditions, and others have influence on the coordination features displayed by this ligand in its complexes. In contrast to molecular (0D) complexes in which bpdc almost always acts as a chelating ligand exclusively via the bipyridine moiety (type g in Scheme ), in one-dimensional chain coordination polymers based on nickel(II) ions and additional N-donor cyclam ligands, [Ni(cyclam)(bpdc)] n , the bpdc ligand only involves carboxylate groups in the bonding and adopts type a in Scheme , while in the 1D copper(II) coordination polymer [Cu(H2bpdc)Cl] n   the coordination occurs also via a bipyridyl moiety. Remarkably, the bpdc ligand often employs both carboxylate groups and the bipyridine unit to form a wide range of two-dimensional networks, which include different homo- or heterometallic centers. For example, in a series of 2D coordination polymers based on homometallic Fe(II), Ni(II), Co(II), and Zn(II) ions and bpdc that have been hydrothermally synthesized, the bpdc ligand used all donor sites to build up an extended network. Similar behavior is observed in the heterometallic 2D polymers that include Pt(II)/Y(III), Pt(II)/Gd(III), Pt(II)/Rb(I), and Ru(IV)/Zn(II) ions, except a Cu(II)/V(IV)-based coordination polymer with coordination only to the bipyridine moiety. In the case of three-dimensional coordination polymers of Nd(III), K(I), Zn(II), and Sm(III), the bpdc used carboxylate groups to bind the metal centers and its N donor sites were left open, while in homo- or heterometallic MOFs of Pb(II), Zn(II), Mn(II), Ru(II)/Zn(II), Mn(I)/Mn(II), and Re(I)/Mn (II), all donor sites of bpdc bind. Note that the Ru(II) and Pt(II) complexes with bpdc, [Ru(Hbpdc)2(X)2], and [Pt(bpdc)(tdt)] (tdt = 3,4-toluenedithiolate) and its tetrabutylammoium salt, attached to a TiO2 substrate, have been used as sensitizers in solar cells. The aforementioned linear Ni(II) coordination polymers with open bpdc N-donor sites exhibit permanent porosity, hydrogen storage capacity, and selective organic guest binding ability.

elements.content: Recently, we successfully developed a new series of polynuclear Ce(III/IV) clusters and one-dimensional Ce(III) coordination polymers based on isobutyric and propionic acids. Our motivation for choosing Ce(III) is its large ionic radius and the ability to adopt various coordination geometries. In continuing this research on the structural coordination chemistry of Ce(III), we herein report two new cerium(III) MOFs based on the 2,2′-bipyridine-5,5′-dicarboxylate, namely, {[Ce2(H2O)(bpdc)3(dmf)2]·2(dmf)} n (1) and {[Ce4(H2O)5(bpdc)6(dmf)]·x(dmf)} n (2, x ≈ 5). MOFs 1 and 2 were characterized by single-crystal and powder X-ray diffraction studies, IR spectroscopy, thermoanalysis (TGA/DTA), and adsorption measurements to reveal their homogeneity and structural, spectral, and thermal properties and sorption capacities. Furthermore, 1 was analyzed magnetochemically.
elements.clean_text: Recently, we successfully developed a new series of polynuclear Ce(III/IV) clusters and one-dimensional Ce(III) coordination polymers based on isobutyric and propionic acids. Our motivation for choosing Ce(III) is its large ionic radius and the ability to adopt various coordination geometries. In continuing this research on the structural coordination chemistry of Ce(III), we herein report two new cerium(III) MOFs based on the 2,2'-bipyridine-5,5'-dicarboxylate, namely, {[Ce2(H2O)(bpdc)3(dmf)2]⋅2(dmf)} n  (1) and {[Ce4(H2O)5(bpdc)6(dmf)]⋅x(dmf)} n  (2, x ~ 5). MOFs 1 and 2 were characterized by single-crystal and powder X-ray diffraction studies, IR spectroscopy, thermoanalysis (TGA/DTA), and adsorption measurements to reveal their homogeneity and structural, spectral, and thermal properties and sorption capacities. Furthermore, 1 was analyzed magnetochemically.

elements.content: All reagents were purchased from commercial sources and reacted without further purification. IR spectra (400 to 4000 cm–1) were recorded with a Nicolet Avatar 360 FT-IR ESP spectrometer using KBr pellets. TGA/DTA up to 1000 °C utilized a Mettler Toledo TGA/SDTA851 instrument under N2 flow (60 mL min–1) at a heating rate of 10 K min–1. BET measurements and the adsorption/desorption isotherms were carried out on BELSORP-max gas adsorption systems for N2 at 77 K, and CO2 at room temperature. To prepare the samples for the actual measurements, the crystals were heated to 200 °C and kept under vacuum overnight.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and General Methods

All reagents were purchased from commercial sources and reacted without further purification. IR spectra (400 to 4000 cm-1) were recorded with a Nicolet Avatar 360 FT-IR ESP spectrometer using KBr pellets. TGA/DTA up to 1000 °C utilized a Mettler Toledo TGA/SDTA851 instrument under N2 flow (60 mL min-1) at a heating rate of 10 K min-1. BET measurements and the adsorption/desorption isotherms were carried out on BELSORP-max gas adsorption systems for N2 at 77 K, and CO2 at room temperature. To prepare the samples for the actual measurements, the crystals were heated to 200 °C and kept under vacuum overnight.

elements.content: Magnetic susceptibility data for 1 were obtained using a Quantum Design MPMS-5XL SQUID magnetometer. Polycrystalline samples were compacted and immobilized into cylindrical PTFE capsules. Data were acquired as a function of the field (0–5 T) and temperature (2–290 K) and corrected for the contribution of the sample holder (PTFE capsule) and calculated diamagnetic contributions (χdia(1) = −6.2 × 10–4 cm3 mol–1).
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Characterization

Magnetic susceptibility data for 1 were obtained using a Quantum Design MPMS-5XL SQUID magnetometer. Polycrystalline samples were compacted and immobilized into cylindrical PTFE capsules. Data were acquired as a function of the field (0-5 T) and temperature (2-290 K) and corrected for the contribution of the sample holder (PTFE capsule) and calculated diamagnetic contributions (χdia(1) = -6.2 × 10-4 cm3 mol-1).

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction experiments for 1 and 2 were carried out on a Bruker APEX CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation at 153 K for 1 and 100 K for 2. The positions of almost all non-hydrogen atoms were found by direct methods. The remaining atoms were located in an alternating series of least-squares cycles on difference Fourier maps. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined in full-matrix anisotropic approximation. All hydrogen atoms were placed in the structure factor calculation at idealized positions and were allowed to ride on the respective carbon atoms with relative isotropic displacement coefficients. SIMU, DELU, and EADP restraints were used to obtain reasonable displacement coefficients. One of the dmf molecules coordinated to cerium(III) in 2 was found objectively and refined. All other vacant positions in the Ce(III) coordination sphere were considered to be coordinated water ligand. The only reason for this decision was a possibility to refine objectively only oxygen positions. On the other side, there are many high peaks around those atoms that could represent highly disordered dmf. All attempts to find the model for this disorder failed even with a rough DFIX approach. SQUEEZE indicated existence of approximately nine diffused dmf molecules per asymmetric unit. The final formula was corrected taking into account diffused solvent to obtain true metric information. Crystallographic data and structure refinement parameters for 1 and 2 are summarized in Table ; selected bond distances for 1 and 2 are summarized in Table . CCDC 988589 and 988590 contain the supplementary crystallographic data for 1 and 2, respectively. These data can be obtained free of charge from The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif. Powder X-ray diffraction was performed on a Stoe Stadi P diffractometer (transmission geometry) using Cu Kα1 radiation equipped with an image plate detector, collecting 2θ steps of 0.015°.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction experiments for 1 and 2 were carried out on a Bruker APEX CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation at 153 K for 1 and 100 K for 2. The positions of almost all non-hydrogen atoms were found by direct methods. The remaining atoms were located in an alternating series of least-squares cycles on difference Fourier maps. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined in full-matrix anisotropic approximation. All hydrogen atoms were placed in the structure factor calculation at idealized positions and were allowed to ride on the respective carbon atoms with relative isotropic displacement coefficients. SIMU, DELU, and EADP restraints were used to obtain reasonable displacement coefficients. One of the dmf molecules coordinated to cerium(III) in 2 was found objectively and refined. All other vacant positions in the Ce(III) coordination sphere were considered to be coordinated water ligand. The only reason for this decision was a possibility to refine objectively only oxygen positions. On the other side, there are many high peaks around those atoms that could represent highly disordered dmf. All attempts to find the model for this disorder failed even with a rough DFIX approach. SQUEEZE indicated existence of approximately nine diffused dmf molecules per asymmetric unit. The final formula was corrected taking into account diffused solvent to obtain true metric information. Crystallographic data and structure refinement parameters for 1 and 2 are summarized in Table ; selected bond distances for 1 and 2 are summarized in Table . CCDC 988589 and 988590 contain the supplementary crystallographic data for 1 and 2, respectively. These data can be obtained free of charge from The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif. Powder X-ray diffraction was performed on a Stoe Stadi P diffractometer (transmission geometry) using Cu Kα1 radiation equipped with an image plate detector, collecting 2θ steps of 0.015°.

A mixture of Ce(NO3)3·6H2O (0.1085 g, 0.25 mmol), bpdc (0.0305 g, 0.125 mmol), and 4,4′-bipyridine (0.0195 g, 0.125 mmol) in 4 mL of dimethylformamide was placed in a 12 mL PTFE-lined stainless steel autoclave. The mixture was heated to 120 °C within 1 h, then kept at this temperature for 5 h and cooled to ambient temperature within 48 h. The light-yellow crystals of 1 were filtered off, washed with dmf, and dried in air. Yield: 0.0553 g, 67% based on bpdc. Elemental Anal. Calcd for C48H48Ce2N10O17: C, 43.8; H, 3.7; N, 10.6%. Found: C, 42.5; H, 3.3; N, 9.7%. IR (KBr pellet, ν/cm–1): 3421 br/m, 3051 w, 1596 s, 1565 s, 1510 s, 1400 vs, 1247 w, 1159 w, 1122 w, 1054 w, 1025 m, 860 w, 846 w, 784 s, 699 w, 552 m, 535 m, 411 m.
elements.clean_text:
Syntheses

{[Ce2(H2O)(bpdc)3(dmf)2]⋅2(dmf)} n  (1)

A mixture of Ce(NO3)3⋅6H2O (0.1085 g, 0.25 mmol), bpdc (0.0305 g, 0.125 mmol), and 4,4'-bipyridine (0.0195 g, 0.125 mmol) in 4 mL of dimethylformamide was placed in a 12 mL PTFE-lined stainless steel autoclave. The mixture was heated to 120 °C within 1 h, then kept at this temperature for 5 h and cooled to ambient temperature within 48 h. The light-yellow crystals of 1 were filtered off, washed with dmf, and dried in air. Yield: 0.0553 g, 67% based on bpdc. Elemental Anal. Calcd for C48H48Ce2N10O17: C, 43.8; H, 3.7; N, 10.6%. Found: C, 42.5; H, 3.3; N, 9.7%. IR (KBr pellet, ν/cm-1): 3421 br/m, 3051 w, 1596 s, 1565 s, 1510 s, 1400 vs, 1247 w, 1159 w, 1122 w, 1054 w, 1025 m, 860 w, 846 w, 784 s, 699 w, 552 m, 535 m, 411 m.

elements.content: MOF 1, {[Ce2(H2O)(bpdc)3(dmf)2]·2(dmf)} n , was synthesized by solvothermal reaction at 120 °C for 5 h of Ce(NO3)3·6H2O, bpdc, and 4,4′-bpy in a molar ratio of 2:1:1 in 4 mL of dimethylformamide. After cooling of the mixture during 48 h to room temperature, the light-yellow crystals of 1 were recovered in a good yield of 67%. Although the 4,4′-bpy ligand does not coordinate in the product, its presence is crucial for the growth of crystalline product, and only poorly defined microcrystalline product can be obtained without it. Moreover, a stoichiometric ratio corresponding to the ratio of metal to ligand in the final structure (2:3) only yielded a powdery precipitate. MOF 2, {[Ce4(H2O)5(bpdc)6(dmf)]·x(dmf)} n , was synthesized under the same conditions as 1 but using a more concentrated solution without any additional 4,4′-bpy. The light-yellow crystals of 2 were obtained in much better yield of 84%. Compound 1 is stable in air, whereas the crystals of 2 partly decompose, losing some solvent molecules after drying in air. Comparison of data from elemental analysis and thermogravimetrical study indicates approximately five dmf molecules in the network. Both MOFs are insoluble in water and common organic solvents.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis and Preliminary Characterization

MOF 1, {[Ce2(H2O)(bpdc)3(dmf)2]⋅2(dmf)} n , was synthesized by solvothermal reaction at 120 °C for 5 h of Ce(NO3)3⋅6H2O, bpdc, and 4,4'-bpy in a molar ratio of 2:1:1 in 4 mL of dimethylformamide. After cooling of the mixture during 48 h to room temperature, the light-yellow crystals of 1 were recovered in a good yield of 67%. Although the 4,4'-bpy ligand does not coordinate in the product, its presence is crucial for the growth of crystalline product, and only poorly defined microcrystalline product can be obtained without it. Moreover, a stoichiometric ratio corresponding to the ratio of metal to ligand in the final structure (2:3) only yielded a powdery precipitate. MOF 2, {[Ce4(H2O)5(bpdc)6(dmf)]⋅x(dmf)} n , was synthesized under the same conditions as 1 but using a more concentrated solution without any additional 4,4'-bpy. The light-yellow crystals of 2 were obtained in much better yield of 84%. Compound 1 is stable in air, whereas the crystals of 2 partly decompose, losing some solvent molecules after drying in air. Comparison of data from elemental analysis and thermogravimetrical study indicates approximately five dmf molecules in the network. Both MOFs are insoluble in water and common organic solvents.

elements.content: The IR spectra of 1 and 2 show characteristic strong and broad bands for the coordinated carboxylate groups of bpdc ligand in the range of 1592–1563 cm–1 for the asymmetric stretching and in the range of 1401–1396 cm–1 for symmetric stretching. These bands overlap the stretching vibrations associated with the ν(CN) bonds of the pyridyl-containing ligands. In addition, the peaks in the region of 1674–1597 cm–1 can be ascribed to the −CHO stretching vibration of dmf molecules. Various features in the range of 3054–2857 cm–1 can be assigned to the C–H stretching vibrations. The presence of the coordinated water molecules in MOFs 1 and 2 is provided by broad signals centered at 3421 and 3439 cm–1, respectively

elements.content: Thermogravimetric analysis of MOF 1 reveals two endothermic mass loss steps. The first weight loss of 11.0% occurs before 200 °C and is attributed to the loss of most solvate molecules per formula unit (calcd 11.1%). Remarkably, the coordination framework appears to be thermally stable up to 480 °C; only at higher temperatures the decomposition of organic components is observed. TGA data for MOF 2 show the first weight loss step of 14.4% up to 150 °C, which corresponds to the loss of five solvate dmf molecules (calcd 14.7%). On further heating, the decomposition of the organic part in 2 occurred in several overlapping steps.

elements.content: The adsorption characteristics of the frameworks in both MOFs were investigated, and their porosity was confirmed by their N2 and CO2 adsorption isotherms at 77 and 298 K, respectively. After desolvation, MOF 1 exhibits surface adsorption with a BET surface area of 10.5 m2 g–1 and a pore volume of 2.41 cm3 (STP) g–1, whereas MOF 2 has a BET surface area of 16.8 m2 g–1 and a higher pore volume of 3.86 cm3 (STP) g–1. The average pore diameter is 2.19 nm for 1 and 2.54 nm for 2. Gas adsorption measurements at 1 bar were performed to investigate the N2 and CO2 uptake capacities of 1 and 2, which are shown in Figures S8–S11 in . After activation at 200 °C under vacuum overnight, MOF 1 can take up 49 cm3 g–1 of nitrogen at 77 K, whereas MOF 2 has a higher capacity and can take up 64 cm3 g–1 of N2 under the same conditions. At room temperature, the adsorption capacities of 1 and 2 for CO2 are 10.7 and 10.4 cm3 g–1, respectively.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis showed that cationic [Ce(dmf)]3+ (1) or [Ce(dmf)]3+ and [Ce(H2O)]3+ (2) units are interconnected by bpdc bridging ligands to generate a neutral 3D metal–organic network with a (4,4) topology and large one-dimensional channels in 1 and 2.
elements.clean_text:
Structural Description

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis showed that cationic [Ce(dmf)]3+ (1) or [Ce(dmf)]3+ and [Ce(H2O)]3+ (2) units are interconnected by bpdc bridging ligands to generate a neutral 3D metal-organic network with a (4,4) topology and large one-dimensional channels in 1 and 2.

elements.content: MOF 1 crystallizes in a monoclinic system, space group P21/c, and the asymmetric unit contains two crystallographically independent Ce1 and Ce2 centers, three bpdc ligands, one bridging water molecule, and two coordinated and two solvate dmf molecules as shown in Figure . Both Ce(III) centers in 1 are eight-coordinated (Ce–O distances <2.9 Å) and adopt a distorted CeO8 square-antiprismatic coordination geometry (Figure a) formed by six O atoms from six bridging carboxylates (Ce–Ocarb, 2.395(11)–2.537(12) Å), one O atom from a bridging water (Ce–OH2O, 2.899(12) and 2.641(12) Å), and an O atom from a dmf molecule (Ce–Odmf, 2.399(13) and 2.519(12) Å) (Table ).

elements.content: In 1, each bpdc2– anion acts as a tetradentate bridging ligand and its two carboxylic groups display a μ2-bridging mode coordinated to four Ce(III) atoms (type c in Scheme ) and connect the adjacent [Ce(dmf)]3+ units to generate undulated 1D chains propagating along the b axis (Figure b). A bridging water molecule (O17) additionally links Ce1 and Ce2 atoms in the chains. Thus, depending on the number of bridging ligands, the Ce···Ce distance varies; Ce1 and Ce2 atoms are bridged by two carboxylate groups from two bpdc and one water molecule (Ce···Ce, 4.834(2) Å), whereas four carboxylate groups of four distinct bpdc moieties form the Ce2···Ce1# link (Ce···Ce, 4.270(2) Å). This results in a Ce1–Ce2–Ce1#–Ce2# sequence with alternating intrachain Ce···Ce separations (Figure S2 in ). As mentioned above, each dmf ligand is ligated to each cerium atom, Ce1 and Ce2, and directed to the empty areas. In the chain, a pair of Ce1 and Ce2 atoms connected by two carboxylate bridges and the water ligand has dmf oriented in one direction along the b axis, whereas the next pair of Ce atoms, Ce1# and Ce2#, has the coordinated dmf molecules oriented in the opposite direction as shown in Figure S3, . Furthermore, the chains are interconnected through the bpdc ligands to generate a 3D network consisting of elongated rhombus-shaped channels with diagonal distances of ca. 11.93(average) × 27.56 Å2 along the c axis (Figure c,d). Note that due to the undulation of the above-mentioned chains, the distances between the metal ions located at opposite sides of rhombs (through the shorter diagonal) are 9.69, 11.69, 12.55, and 13.79 Å. The Ce···Ce distances via bpdc spacers amount to 14.133(2)–14.586(2) Å. The large channels are filled with guest dmf molecules, which show no significant intermolecular interactions (Figure S4, ). Upon removal of these guest molecules, MOF 1 has 22.7% (1166.2 Å3) solvent-accessible voids as calculated by PLATON, out of the total unit cell volume of 5142.2(18) Å3.

MOF 2 crystallizes in a monoclinic system, space group C2/c, and the asymmetric unit consists of four crystallographically independent Ce atoms, Ce1, Ce2, Ce3, and Ce4, six bpdc ligands, one coordinated dmf ligand, three coordinated water molecules (O26, O29, and O31), and bridging water molecules O30, O25, and O27, which occupy a special position (0.5) as shown in Figure . Additional highly disordered lattice dmf molecules were also present, but they were removed by the SQUEEZE program as specified in the and are not shown in Figure . In 2, two unique cerium(III) atoms, Ce1 and Ce2, are eight-coordinated similarly to those in 1, while Ce3 and Ce4 are nine-coordinated. The Ce1 center adopts an O8 square-antiprismatic coordination geometry formed by six O atoms from six bridging bpdc ligands (Ce–Ocarb, 2.443(8)–2.538(6) Å), one O atom of the coordinated water ligand (Ce–O26, 2.476(9) Å), and one O atom from the bridging water molecule (Ce–O25, 2.651(5) Å). The Ce2 atom has an O8 donor set comprising six O atoms from six bpdc ligands (Ce–Ocarb, 2.422(7)–2.558(6) Å), one O atom of a bridging water molecule (Ce–O27, 2.664(5) Å), and one O atom from coordinated dmf (Ce–Odmf, 2.471(9) Å) in a square-antiprismatic environment. Ce3 is coordinated by four O atoms from four bridging bpdc ligands, three O atoms from two chelate carboxylates, one O atom from the coordinated water molecule, and one O atom from bridging water in an O9 coordination environment (Ce–Ocarb, 2.399(8)–2.824(6) Å; Ce–OH2O, 2.482(9) Å for the coordinated molecule (O29) and one significantly longer bond of 2.935(10) Å for the bridging one (O30)). Ce4 also has an O9 donor set from seven carboxylate oxygen atoms of six bpdc ligands: four of them are bridging and three remaining are chelating ones from two carboxylate groups (Ce–Ocarb, 2.416(9)–2.902(9) Å), as well as two water ligands (Ce–O30bridging, 2.631(9) Å; Ce–O31terminal, 2.527(9) Å) (Table ).

elements.content: Similar to 1, all bpdc ligands in 2 are coordinated to four cerium(III) ions, but their carboxylate groups show two different coordination modes: μ2:η2-η1 and μ2:η1-η1. Four crystallographically independent bpdc ligands adopt the c mode from Scheme , where each oxygen carboxylate atom is coordinated to one metal ion (μ2:η1-η1), whereas the fifth and sixth bpdc ligands show both bridging and chelating coordination (μ2:η2-η1 and μ2:η1-η1) and adopt a d mode in Scheme . As a result, bpdc ligands link Ce atoms to generate two kinds of undulated chains as shown in Figure . One of them consists of Ce1 and Ce2 atoms (or [Ce(H2O)] and [Ce(dmf)] units, respectively) organized by bridging carboxylate groups from bpdc and a water linker in a Ce1#–Ce1–Ce2–Ce2# sequence ([Ce(H2O)]#–[Ce(H2O)]–[Ce(dmf)]–[Ce(dmf)]#). The Ce1···Ce2 distance where two metal atoms are bridged by four carboxylate groups from four bpdc equals 4.394(3) Å, whereas the Ce atoms linked by two carboxylate groups from two bpdc and one water ligands (Ce1···C1# and Ce2···Ce2#) have a slightly longer distance of 4.417(4) Å. The other chain is built up from Ce3 and Ce4 atoms. Here, the [Ce(H2O)] groups are linked by both bridging and chelating carboxylate groups and water molecules into a Ce3···Ce4···Ce3# sequence ([Ce(H2O)]–[Ce(H2O)]–[Ce(H2O)]#) with metal···metal separations of 4.208(4) and 4.749(4) Å. The Ce3···Ce4 separation, through two μ2-bridging and two chelate-bridging carboxylates, of 4.208(3) Å is the shortest one. The Ce···Ce distances between adjacent chains, interlinked via bpdc groups, range from 14.23(1) to 15.63(1) Å.

elements.content: Furthermore, two unique undulated chains in 2 are organized by bpdc carboxylate linkers into a 3D network with rhombus-shaped channels along the c direction similar to those observed in 1 (Figure ). The diagonal distances between the metal ions located at opposite sides of the rhombs range from 12.91(2) to 16.60(1) Å through the shorter diagonal and from 26.14(2) to 26.39(2) Å through the longer one. There are two types of rhombus-shaped pores in the network adopted by 2. One of them contains the coordinated dmf molecules oriented to the center of the pores as shown in Figure , and the other one contains only the coordinated water molecules. As a result, the solvent-accessible voids, after removal of lattice solvent molecules in 2, assume a much bigger portion of 47.1% (11889.8 Å3) of the total unit cell volume of 25257.0 Å3 (as calculated by PLATON.)

elements.content: The magnetic susceptibility (0.1 T, 2–290 K) and low-temperature magnetization (0–5 T, 2.0 K) data for 1 (Figure ) have been analyzed using the computational framework CONDON. All microscopic aspects necessary to model the 4f1 electron structure relevant to magnetic single-ion effects are taken into account: ligand-field effects, electron–electron repulsions, spin–orbit coupling, and Zeeman effect. Standard values are employed for spectroscopic parameters and the single-electron spin–orbit coupling parameter (ζ4f = 640 cm–1). A χm T value of 0.745 cm3 K mol–1 at 290 K is close to the pure total angular momentum value of 0.803 cm3 K mol–1 (= g J 2 J(J + 1)N AμB 2/(3k B), g J = 6/7, J = 5/2). χm T continuously decreases when the temperature is lowered indicating primarily single-ion contributions and, to a smaller extent, antiferromagnetic exchange interactions of the Ce(III) centers. The magnetic exchange structure of the chain polymer 1, with alternating distances between the Ce(III) spin centers (4.269 and 4.834 Å), is modeled as a dimer (shorter distance) that interacts with next neighbors by a molecular field (molecular field approximation, λMF). Further, both Ce(III) sites are treated as identical in a D 4d -symmetric ligand field. Thus, the degeneracy of the ground and exited multiplets of the free ion (Ce(III) ground multiplet, 2 F 5/2) are removed. Each Ce(III) center as well their interactions is modeled in the full basis, that is, 14 basis states per center. A least-squares fit (SQ = 1.1%) to the combined field- and temperature-dependent data results in ligand field parameters (Wyborne notation): B 0 2 = −10 cm–1, B 0 4 = −1480 cm–1, and B 0 6 = −520 cm–1.The intradimer coupling is characterized by a Heisenberg-type exchange energy of J = −0.10 cm–1; the molecular field parameter accounting for all interdimer coupling interactions amounts to λMF = −0.193 mol cm–3. This means that all coupling interactions are weakly antiferromagnetic, as expected. The 14 states split into seven Kramer’s doublets. The former ground multiplet splits into three doublets. Normalized to the ground doublet, they are at 0, 89, and 370 cm–1 and belong to m J = ±1/2, m J = ±5/2, and m J = ±3/2 states (according to Hellwege), respectively. The remaining four higher excited doublets are at 22200, 22790, 25210, and 26320 cm–1, respectively.

Standard values are employed for spectroscopic parameters and the single-electron spin-orbit coupling parameter (ζ4f = 640 cm-1). A χm T value of 0.745 cm3 K mol-1 at 290 K is close to the pure total angular momentum value of 0.803 cm3 K mol-1 (= g  J  2 J(J + 1)N AμB 2/(3k B), g  J  = 6/7, J = 5/2). χm T continuously decreases when the temperature is lowered indicating primarily single-ion contributions and, to a smaller extent, antiferromagnetic exchange interactions of the Ce(III) centers. Further, both Ce(III) sites are treated as identical in a D 4d -symmetric ligand field. Thus, the degeneracy of the ground and exited multiplets of the free ion (Ce(III) ground multiplet, 2 F 5/2) are removed. Each Ce(III) center as well their interactions is modeled in the full basis, that is, 14 basis states per center. A least-squares fit (SQ = 1.1%) to the combined field- and temperature-dependent data results in ligand field parameters (Wyborne notation): B 0 2 = -10 cm-1, B 0 4 = -1480 cm-1, and B 0 6 = -520 cm-1.The intradimer coupling is characterized by a Heisenberg-type exchange energy of J = -0.10 cm-1; the molecular field parameter accounting for all interdimer coupling interactions amounts to λMF = -0.193 mol cm-3. This means that all coupling interactions are weakly antiferromagnetic, as expected. The 14 states split into seven Kramer's doublets. The former ground multiplet splits into three doublets. Normalized to the ground doublet, they are at 0, 89, and 370 cm-1 and belong to m  J  = ±1/2, m  J  = ±5/2, and m  J  = ±3/2 states (according to Hellwege), respectively. elements.content: The 3D coordination networks 1 and 2 illustrate the propensity of CeIII ions to adopt distinct coordination environments. This in turn renders CeIII-based coordination networks susceptible even to subtle changes to the reaction conditions, resulting in comparably flexible porous structures that can take up varying amounts of crystal solvent, in the present case dmf molecules. An intriguing aspect of the two presented MOFs are the noncoordinated N donor sites of the bpdc linkers, which represent potential binding sites for sufficiently small transition metal centers that would act as further modifiers to the structurally elastic rhombus-type channel structures of 1 and 2. As expected for Ce(III)-based coordination networks, the magnetism of 1 is characterized predominantly by strong single-ion effects of the 4f1 ions that couple only weakly antiferromagnetically.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

The 3D coordination networks 1 and 2 illustrate the propensity of CeIII ions to adopt distinct coordination environments. This in turn renders CeIII-based coordination networks susceptible even to subtle changes to the reaction conditions, resulting in comparably flexible porous structures that can take up varying amounts of crystal solvent, in the present case dmf molecules. An intriguing aspect of the two presented MOFs are the noncoordinated N donor sites of the bpdc linkers, which represent potential binding sites for sufficiently small transition metal centers that would act as further modifiers to the structurally elastic rhombus-type channel structures of 1 and 2. As expected for Ce(III)-based coordination networks, the magnetism of 1 is characterized predominantly by strong single-ion effects of the 4f1 ions that couple only weakly antiferromagnetically.

A mixture of Ce(NO3)3·6H2O (0.1085 g, 0.25 mmol), bpdc (0.0305 g, 0.125 mmol), and 4,4′-bipyridine (0.0195 g, 0.125 mmol) in 4 mL of dimethylformamide was placed in a 12 mL PTFE-lined stainless steel autoclave. The mixture was heated to 120 °C within 1 h, then kept at this temperature for 5 h and cooled to ambient temperature within 48 h. The light-yellow crystals of 1 were filtered off, washed with dmf, and dried in air. Yield: 0.0553 g, 67% based on bpdc. Elemental Anal. Calcd for C48H48Ce2N10O17: C, 43.8; H, 3.7; N, 10.6%. Found: C, 42.5; H, 3.3; N, 9.7%. IR (KBr pellet, ν/cm–1): 3421 br/m, 3051 w, 1596 s, 1565 s, 1510 s, 1400 vs, 1247 w, 1159 w, 1122 w, 1054 w, 1025 m, 860 w, 846 w, 784 s, 699 w, 552 m, 535 m, 411 m.

{[Ce<sub>4</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>5</sub>(bpdc)<sub>6</sub>(dmf)]·<italic toggle="yes">x</italic>(dmf)}<italic toggle="yes"> <sub>n</sub> </italic> (<bold>2</bold>)

A mixture of Ce(NO3)3·6H2O (0.1628 g, 0.375 mmol), and bpdc (0.0305 g (0.1875 mmol) in 4 mL of dimethylformamide was placed in a 12 mL PTFE crucible placed in a steel autoclave. The mixture was heated to 120 °C within 1 h, then kept at this temperature for 5 h and cooled to ambient temperature within 48 h. The light yellow crystals of 2 were filtered off, washed with dmf, and dried in air. Yield: 0.0977, 84% based on bpdc. Elemental Anal. Calcd for C90H90Ce4N18O36 (with x = 5): C, 42.2; H, 3.5; N, 9.8%. Found: C, 41.3; H, 3.5; N, 9.8%. IR (KBr pellet, ν/cm–1): 3439 br/m, 3054 w, 2930 w, 2857 w, 2931 br/w, 1674 s, 1623 s, 1595 s, 1530 s, 1400 vs, 1246 w, 1159 w, 1111 w, 1090 w, 1053 w, 1025 w, 959 w, 862 w, 847 w, 814 w, 782 s, 696 w, 674 w, 660 w, 643 w, 540 br/w, 419 m.

Results and DiscussionSynthesis and Preliminary Characterization

MOF 1, {[Ce2(H2O)(bpdc)3(dmf)2]·2(dmf)} n , was synthesized by solvothermal reaction at 120 °C for 5 h of Ce(NO3)3·6H2O, bpdc, and 4,4′-bpy in a molar ratio of 2:1:1 in 4 mL of dimethylformamide. After cooling of the mixture during 48 h to room temperature, the light-yellow crystals of 1 were recovered in a good yield of 67%. Although the 4,4′-bpy ligand does not coordinate in the product, its presence is crucial for the growth of crystalline product, and only poorly defined microcrystalline product can be obtained without it. Moreover, a stoichiometric ratio corresponding to the ratio of metal to ligand in the final structure (2:3) only yielded a powdery precipitate. MOF 2, {[Ce4(H2O)5(bpdc)6(dmf)]·x(dmf)} n , was synthesized under the same conditions as 1 but using a more concentrated solution without any additional 4,4′-bpy. The light-yellow crystals of 2 were obtained in much better yield of 84%. Compound 1 is stable in air, whereas the crystals of 2 partly decompose, losing some solvent molecules after drying in air. Comparison of data from elemental analysis and thermogravimetrical study indicates approximately five dmf molecules in the network. Both MOFs are insoluble in water and common organic solvents.

Results and Discussion

Synthesis and Preliminary Characterization

MOF 1, {[Ce2(H2O)(bpdc)3(dmf)2]⋅2(dmf)} n , was synthesized by solvothermal reaction at 120 °C for 5 h of Ce(NO3)3⋅6H2O, bpdc, and 4,4'-bpy in a molar ratio of 2:1:1 in 4 mL of dimethylformamide. After cooling of the mixture during 48 h to room temperature, the light-yellow crystals of 1 were recovered in a good yield of 67%. Although the 4,4'-bpy ligand does not coordinate in the product, its presence is crucial for the growth of crystalline product, and only poorly defined microcrystalline product can be obtained without it. Moreover, a stoichiometric ratio corresponding to the ratio of metal to ligand in the final structure (2:3) only yielded a powdery precipitate. MOF 2, {[Ce4(H2O)5(bpdc)6(dmf)]⋅x(dmf)} n , was synthesized under the same conditions as 1 but using a more concentrated solution without any additional 4,4'-bpy. The light-yellow crystals of 2 were obtained in much better yield of 84%. Compound 1 is stable in air, whereas the crystals of 2 partly decompose, losing some solvent molecules after drying in air. Comparison of data from elemental analysis and thermogravimetrical study indicates approximately five dmf molecules in the network. Both MOFs are insoluble in water and common organic solvents.

cln_elements.content:
Thermogravimetric analysis of MOF 1 reveals two endothermic mass loss steps. The first weight loss of 11.0% occurs before 200 °C and is attributed to the loss of most solvate molecules per formula unit (calcd 11.1%). Remarkably, the coordination framework appears to be thermally stable up to 480 °C; only at higher temperatures the decomposition of organic components is observed. TGA data for MOF 2 show the first weight loss step of 14.4% up to 150 °C, which corresponds to the loss of five solvate dmf molecules (calcd 14.7%). On further heating, the decomposition of the organic part in 2 occurred in several overlapping steps.

The adsorption characteristics of the frameworks in both MOFs were investigated, and their porosity was confirmed by their N2 and CO2 adsorption isotherms at 77 and 298 K, respectively. After desolvation, MOF 1 exhibits surface adsorption with a BET surface area of 10.5 m2 g–1 and a pore volume of 2.41 cm3 (STP) g–1, whereas MOF 2 has a BET surface area of 16.8 m2 g–1 and a higher pore volume of 3.86 cm3 (STP) g–1. The average pore diameter is 2.19 nm for 1 and 2.54 nm for 2. Gas adsorption measurements at 1 bar were performed to investigate the N2 and CO2 uptake capacities of 1 and 2, which are shown in Figures S8–S11 in . After activation at 200 °C under vacuum overnight, MOF 1 can take up 49 cm3 g–1 of nitrogen at 77 K, whereas MOF 2 has a higher capacity and can take up 64 cm3 g–1 of N2 under the same conditions. At room temperature, the adsorption capacities of 1 and 2 for CO2 are 10.7 and 10.4 cm3 g–1, respectively.

Furthermore, two unique undulated chains in 2 are organized by bpdc carboxylate linkers into a 3D network with rhombus-shaped channels along the c direction similar to those observed in 1 (Figure ). The diagonal distances between the metal ions located at opposite sides of the rhombs range from 12.91(2) to 16.60(1) Å through the shorter diagonal and from 26.14(2) to 26.39(2) Å through the longer one. There are two types of rhombus-shaped pores in the network adopted by 2. One of them contains the coordinated dmf molecules oriented to the center of the pores as shown in Figure , and the other one contains only the coordinated water molecules. As a result, the solvent-accessible voids, after removal of lattice solvent molecules in 2, assume a much bigger portion of 47.1% (11889.8 Å3) of the total unit cell volume of 25257.0 Å3 (as calculated by PLATON.)

Magnetochemical Analysis

The magnetic susceptibility (0.1 T, 2–290 K) and low-temperature magnetization (0–5 T, 2.0 K) data for 1 (Figure ) have been analyzed using the computational framework CONDON. All microscopic aspects necessary to model the 4f1 electron structure relevant to magnetic single-ion effects are taken into account: ligand-field effects, electron–electron repulsions, spin–orbit coupling, and Zeeman effect. Standard values are employed for spectroscopic parameters and the single-electron spin–orbit coupling parameter (ζ4f = 640 cm–1). A χm T value of 0.745 cm3 K mol–1 at 290 K is close to the pure total angular momentum value of 0.803 cm3 K mol–1 (= g J 2 J(J + 1)N AμB 2/(3k B), g J = 6/7, J = 5/2). χm T continuously decreases when the temperature is lowered indicating primarily single-ion contributions and, to a smaller extent, antiferromagnetic exchange interactions of the Ce(III) centers. The magnetic exchange structure of the chain polymer 1, with alternating distances between the Ce(III) spin centers (4.269 and 4.834 Å), is modeled as a dimer (shorter distance) that interacts with next neighbors by a molecular field (molecular field approximation, λMF). Further, both Ce(III) sites are treated as identical in a D 4d -symmetric ligand field. Thus, the degeneracy of the ground and exited multiplets of the free ion (Ce(III) ground multiplet, 2 F 5/2) are removed. Each Ce(III) center as well their interactions is modeled in the full basis, that is, 14 basis states per center. A least-squares fit (SQ = 1.1%) to the combined field- and temperature-dependent data results in ligand field parameters (Wyborne notation): B 0 2 = −10 cm–1, B 0 4 = −1480 cm–1, and B 0 6 = −520 cm–1.The intradimer coupling is characterized by a Heisenberg-type exchange energy of J = −0.10 cm–1; the molecular field parameter accounting for all interdimer coupling interactions amounts to λMF = −0.193 mol cm–3. This means that all coupling interactions are weakly antiferromagnetic, as expected. The 14 states split into seven Kramer’s doublets. The former ground multiplet splits into three doublets. Normalized to the ground doublet, they are at 0, 89, and 370 cm–1 and belong to m J = ±1/2, m J = ±5/2, and m J = ±3/2 states (according to Hellwege), respectively. The remaining four higher excited doublets are at 22200, 22790, 25210, and 26320 cm–1, respectively.

cln_elements.content: (a) The distorted square-antiprismatic (Ce1)O8 coordination polyhedron in 1. (b) Formation of undulated 1D chains running along the b axis in 1. Color scheme: C atoms, gray sticks; N atoms, blue sticks, O atoms, red sticks; Ce atoms, green balls. (d) Schematic illustration of a rhombus-shaped channel in 1.
cln_elements.clean_text: 2  (a) The distorted square-antiprismatic (Ce1)O8 coordination polyhedron in 1. (b) Formation of undulated 1D chains running along the b axis in 1. Color scheme: C atoms, gray sticks; N atoms, blue sticks, O atoms, red sticks; Ce atoms, green balls. (d) Schematic illustration of a rhombus-shaped channel in 1.
